As Little Design as Possible

Xerox Corporation | Lead Design | 2000

Network scanners disrupted the traditional one-to-one relationship between scanners and computers, introducing complexities in user experience.

Research

Interviews with IT administrators at larger companies revealed:

  • Becasue previous solutions demanded technical knowledge or tedious setup processes this was not a task for end-users.
  • Configuration of client PCs for network scanning was unlikely to be undertaken for all users.

My goal was to create a seamless connection between networked scanners and computers, minimizing any configuration. This led to the development of a simplified workflow for Xerox Client network scanning software.

Here is the simplified workflow I developed for Xerox Client software for network scanning:

Step #0. No Configuration Questions

(Not really a step but a big improvement!) The software magically discovers installed scanners, giving the user access to associated services. (A list of available network scanners will appear in the list. Opening this window optional.)

Step #1 . Walk-up and scan using your template

Templates automatically created with the user's login name. This happens magically without the intervention of the user or administrator.

Step #2. Return to your desk and the file is waiting

No end-user configuration required. User notification automatically configured at install. Users may choose other outcomes for their scans.

Note: This design may have influenced Microsoft's "Scanners and Cameras" feature in Windows XP (released in late 2001), though Microsoft's version didn't include network scanners at launch.

User Experience Improvements

Simplified Installation
  • Old: Required technical knowledge, limited to administrators
  • New: Accessible to all users
Zero-Configuration
  • Software auto-detects eligible network machines
  • Enables enterprise-wide distribution
Automatic Template Creation
  • Old: Manual configuration required
  • New: Automatic setup for scanning to any connected machine
User-Friendly Administration
  • Eliminated need for system-wide individual administration by IT
Flexible Scan Management
  • Recipients control scan destination (desktop, email, fax, etc.)
